qas.question: What is an example of a rotary engine without pistons?
What parts of a conventional reciprocating steam engine could be replaced by a pistonless rotary engine?
Along with wear, what development makes it difficult to seal the rotors in an engine that lacks pistons?
What is an example of a rotary engine without leakage?
What parts of a conventional reciprocating steam engine could be replaced by a pistonless valve gear?
What development, along with wear, makes it difficult to seal the rotors in an engine that lacks steam?
What is not based on a pistonless rotary engine?

context: It is possible to use a mechanism based on a pistonless rotary engine such as <a0_2>the <a0_0><a0_1><b3_0><b7_0>Wankel<b3_0/><a0_1/><a0_0/> engine<b7_0/><a0_2/> in place of the <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b4_0>cylinders and valve gear<b4_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> of a conventional reciprocating steam engine. Many such engines have been designed, from the time of James Watt to the present day, but relatively few were actually built and even fewer went into quantity production; see link at bottom of article for more details. The major problem is the <b6_0>difficulty of sealing the rotors<b6_0/> to make them steam-tight in the face of wear and <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b5_0>thermal expansion<b5_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>; the resulting leakage made them very inefficient. Lack of expansive working, or any means of control of the cutoff is also a serious problem with many such designs.[citation needed]
